awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: Collaborative Multi-Robot Systems with Provable Availability, Safety, and Optimality Guarantees
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years, collaborative multi-robot systems have had great initial success in industrial applications. Notable examples include the deployment of automated straddle carriers at container shipping ports (e.g., Brisbane, Rotterdam, Los Angeles) and the use of mobile robots at order fulfillment centers of online retailers (e.g., Amazon). Operational efficiency plays a pivotal role in the viability of these multi-robot systems, the underlying structure of which is yet to be fully understood. A thorough investigation of large-scale collaborative multi-robot systems will lead to solutions for the effective routing of many robots in dynamic and dense settings with provable availability, safety, and optimality guarantees, which will help lower the barrier of entry for industrial multi-robot applications and contribute to productivity increases of the US labor force.

Algorithmic issues rising from the domain possess unique features that distinguish them from well-studied problems. On one hand, classical pickup and delivery problems (PDP) do not model the non-trivial geometry of physical robots and the possible collisions among multiple robots sharing a limited workspace. On the other, multi-robot path and motion planning research has yet to systematically address the coordination of hundreds to thousands of robots for the continuous execution of dynamic and stochastic tasks. The proposed study intends to fill this gap between research and application through the modeling and subsequent algorithmic resolution of the problem, which we call the dynamic multi-robot dispatching problem (DMD). Depending on the specific application domain, DMD may be subdivided into unlabeled (e.g., container unloading from ships) and labeled (e.g., order fulfillment) variants, providing rich grounds for structural exploration. Despite the fact that optimal multi-robot coordination is a computationally intractable problem, preliminary efforts indicate that approximately optimal solutions could be computed in polynomial time, through the careful integration of the state-of-the-art multi-robot motion planners and the global coordination of robot flows. Following this route, the proposed research will develop algorithmic solutions for DMD with provable availability and optimality guarantees under stringent safety assurances for human co-workers. Working with collaborators, the research will also seek to maximize its applicability to industrial setups.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The ever increasing demand in processing and shipping of everyday goods in e-commerce applications renders it highly attractive to develop collaborative multi-robot systems to help human workers with keeping the flow of goods at huge volumes. With this in mind, this NRI project set out to understand the complex interactions in multi-robot systems and use the gained insight to develop high-performance algorithms for facilitating the path/motion planning for such systems, with broad applications in logistics.

Intellectual merit

During the multiple performance periods of the project, significant progress on theories and algorithms on the topic of multi-robot path/motion planning has been made.

On the theoretical front, two core results concerning multi-robot coordination are developed. The first result, developed for a problem we named as Rubik Tables, investigates the general task of rearranging items on lattices using lower dimensional shuffles (e.g., for a 2D lattices, we may perform arbitrary shuffles of items on rows and columns, one at a time). Via a novel application of Hall's matching results adapted to our setting, we show that arbitrarily arranged items can be ordered with surprisingly high efficiency. We further show that the Rubik Table result is general and applies to many challenging object rearrangement problems.

Based on the Rubik Table result, we were able to make a major theoretical breakthrough in multi-robot motion planning, which is the second core theoretical development under the project. More specifically, we show that multi-robot motion planning problems can be solved in polynomial time with  good optimality guarantees. Previously, despite decades of research, it was not known whether polynomial time algorithms with (constant factor) optimality guarantees are even possible. These theoretical results are expected to bring further advances in the development of multi-robot systems theory and applications.

On the algorithmic front, we developed several highly efficient, near-optimal algorithms for coordinating a large number of robots for both static and dynamic settings. In our algorithmic efforts, we made pushes in several directions; we highlight two here. In one direction, we developed complete algorithms for computing high-quality solutions for routing robots at over 50% robot density, which is a density level that is 5-10 times of what was possible. In another, we developed effective heuristics that greatly enhanced the speed and scalability of many state-of-the-art algorithms for multi-robot path/motion planning. We expect these algorithmic efforts to bring big efficiency gains to many practical logistic applications, e.g., at modern robotic warehouses.

Broader impacts

The seminal results developed under the project were disseminated at well-respected venues including IJRR (2), RA-L (6), RSS (6), WAFR (3), ICRA (7), and IROS (2). For a majority of these works, source code has been provided as open-source contributions. Under the project, the PI's team has further developed a fully open-source, affordable hardware-software multi-robot platform for research and education, microMVP (https://arc.cs.rutgers.edu/mvp/).

Throughout the project, the PI kept close contact with relevant industrial partners, e.g., Amazon Robotics, to understand practical needs from the industry and incorporated the received feedback in the development of the results. The interaction has made the products of this project more practical. 

In 2019, the PI co-organized the 2nd IEEE Multi-Robot and Multi-Agent Systems (MRS) conference at Rutgers University. In 2020, the PI co-organized the 14th International Workshop on the Algorithmic Foundations of Robotics (WAFR), an online event.

The project has exposed K-12 and undergraduate students to research. Three undergraduate students published top conference publications, including first author publications.  Incoming PhD students had the opportunity to co-author with more senior students. More senior students were involved in mentoring activities. The PI mentored high school students that went on to CMU, NYU, and Brown.

The PI co-developed a new course in Computer Science at Rutgers University, titled "Introduction to Computational Robotics", which is offered to both undergraduate and graduate students. Through this course as well as graduate seminars, the PI introduced and covered results coming out of this project. For instance, connection is made between practical tasks of rearranging objects and NP-hardness, as the computational complexity of robotics challenges is being discussed in the class.


Last Modified: 01/26/2022
Modified by: Jingjin Yu
